Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Galaxies within Clusters: A New Probe of Dark Energy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative program will develop and implement a new technique for measuring the growth of dark matter structure from galaxy clustering. While most techniques that use galaxy clustering to constrain cosmological parameters focus on measurements at the largest scales, the investigators aim to use clustering at the smallest scales, making full use of the information available in the data with the goal of developing a new cosmological probe based on the relationship between galaxies and dark matter halos that can be applied to existing data and future surveys. This approach could develop into a leading probe of dark energy and other cosmological parameters with the next generation of photometric surveys.

Broader impacts of the work include training of graduate students, release of computer code to the community, and outreach via public lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project demonstrated that it is possible to use the spatial distribution of galaxies at non-linear scales to extract robust cosmological constraints. Galaxy bias-- the difference in the spatial clustering of galaxies and dark matter-- is a function influenced not only by gravity but also by the complicated physics of galaxy formation. When fluctuations are non-linear, this bias depends sensitively on scale and galaxy type. However, by parameterizing this galaxy bias through a statistical connection between galaxies and dark matter halos, we demonstrated that it is possible to "marginalize over the physics of galaxy formation" and recover cosmological information.

This project focused on combining the small-scale two-point correlation function of galaxies and the occupation of galaxies in massive clusters found in optical surveys. We tested our framework on multiple simulations with various methods of paiting galaxies onto halos, as well as several semi-analytic models of galaxy formation. For the latter, the input parameters were varied between "reasonable" models and entirely unphysical models that produce wildly different galaxy distributions upon the same dark matter distribution. In each of these models, our analysis correctly recovers the input cosmological model.

This work further developed methods of finding and characterizing galaxy clusters in optical surveys, yeilding robust cluster catalogs from public SDSS data. Upcoming optical imaging surveys, such as DES and LSST, will produce larger optical cluster catalogs, and our analysis framework will increase their ability to determine cosmological parameters, including the dark energy equation of state.

Broader Impacts: This project was the primary dissertation project of two graduate students, including one female graduate student, who were trained in cutting edge computational and statistical techniques as well as in modern galaxy formation and cosmology research.  The project provided additional training for postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduates.  We also publicly released cosmological simulation data that has broad use for other scientific studies.
